title: Does pure or true objectivity exist? - Quora

response.answer_text: That largely depends on just what you mean by ‘pure objectivity’; allow me to explain. Pure objectivity could mean several different things: A subjective perspective which somehow avoids being tainted by the nature of subjectivity - biases and limitations. This is pure objectivity articulated subjectively.Reality as merely the object of existence, paying no heed to the perceptions of subjects entailed by that object - this is pure objectivity or Truth, defined by me as that which is, as it is, independently of subjective perceptions of it, and this Truth doesn’t require subjective articulation.Reality as the object of existence entirely excluding subjects, pure objectivity could mean the abject denial of subjectivity in favour of the purity of its opposite. This ‘pure objectivity’ is entirely abstract to our experience and it cannot be coherently thought of - our mere thinking about it degrades its purity, because it means that subjectivity exists to contemplate it.If you mean the first, then I’d say it doesn’t exist as far as I know, and I don’t know how it could ever really be achieved; we can approximate it, and perhaps get very close, but I don’t see how you could entirely shed subjective limitations while retaining the status of subject. If you mean the second, then yes I think that exists. I would say the object of existence is the absolute grounding for both our physical system and our subjective experience - pure objectivity which entails subjectivity is, simply put, complete reality. If you mean the third, no. I don’t think that exists and it seems manifestly incoherent to me since I’m here to talk about it. I hope that helped :)

Some philosophers maintain that True Objectivity is possible, while others do not. Generally, from Socrates to John Locke, we find most philosophers will maintain that True Objectivity is possible, and even easy. It is mainly after the rise of David Hume (ca. 1750) and his thought-provoking works on Skepticism, that Western Philosophy has seriously doubted the possibility of people attaining True Objectivity. This tendency increased with Immanuel Kant (1780), then further increased with Arthur Schopenhauer (1820), then exploded with Friedrich Nietzsche (1880) and his doctrine of the Will to Power. In the view of Hume, we can only trust our five senses, and these fail to provide enough data for us to achieve Total Objectivity. For Kant, we can add to our five senses the a priori synthetic Categories of the Pure Understanding, but even these will fail to provide enough data for us to achieve Total Objectivity. For Nietzsche, we never contact Objective Reality — we can only see the world through our individual Will to Power — and that is all we can ever really know. GWF Hegel, back in 1810, challenged Immanuel Kant and those who would agree with him. For Hegel, the human mind is powerful enough to grasp Objective Reality, the Absolute Idea, the Geist, and although this has not yet been attained by the majority, it can be, by using Dialectical Logic and his Encyclopedic Outline. Karl Marx failed to grasp Hegel’s meaning, although he believed he did grasp it, and he told the world that his Socialist political position was “Left Hegelian.” That is nonsense. In any case, even Marx denied that we attain Total Objectivity, because the majority, the working class, is dominated by “ruling class ideology.” And for that reason, he claimed, only the Marxist has seen Objective Reality, so that the majority of workers should (blindly) follow the Marxists. The USSR was created in 1918 due to such Non-Objective thinking, and it and fell in 1990, because it’s dream failed to match Objective Reality. In conclusion, in order to grasp True Objectivity we must get back to Hegel.

I’m interpreting your question to mean is it possible for people to have pure or objective knowledge. To experience reality objectively would seem to be impossible, since each of us looks though a certain set of lenses. In other words, because we are products of given cultures and develop certain world views, preconceptions, and biases, we interpret the world and experiences of the world accordingly. So how can anyone claim to have a truly objective view of reality? Well, it’s not as though no one has ever attempted to view and experience reality without preconceptions or biases. One attempt that comes to mind is phenomenology and the “phenomenological reduction” and the “experience of astonishment.” The idea here is that my immediate experience of a phenomena, prior to my preconceptions kicking in, is when I may have a “pure or objective” view of reality. Another source to explore when attempting objectivity is “On Education,” by Krishnamurti. His ideas on what education should consist of involves developing a consciousness that sees what is, i.e., that sees reality. There isn’t space here to explain his teachings on how to do this, but a phrase that he is famous for is to “observe the observer.” I’m not sure if either the phenomenologists or Krishnamurti’s teaching are entirely successful in leading one to a true objectivity. Perhaps we can only approach objectivity on a continuum. It’s a really interesting idea to investigate.
